Award.AwardTitle: Dissertation Research: Chemical, microbiological and biological evaluation of nutritional deficiencies

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project documents the history of nutrition science in Puerto Rico in the twentieth century from the Great Depression when the island was known for its malnutrition, through the post war recasting of malnutrition as an exclusively biomedical condition to be treated by food enrichment and supplementation technologies, to the 1960s when a survey conducted by the Department of Biochemistry and Nutrition at Puerto Rico's School of Medicine determined that obesity had become a national problem.

The research will result in a dissertation and results will be shared with interested scientists at the University of Puerto Rico and to a broader audience in Puerto Rico via online forums.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This dissertation project is a historical study of scientific, policy, and political ideas about nutrition in mid-twentieth century Puerto Rico. It explores how the emergence, implications, and reconfigurations of ideas about nutrition and malnutrition placed the island in regional and global networks of knowledge and techniques. For this, it traces the disciplinary, institutional, and political exchanges that shaped the ways in which nutrition expertise was created and applied in Puerto Rico. With this framework, the dissertation also analyzes the local manifestations of global scientific and public health dynamics.

To accomplish these objectives, the dissertation first examines how nutrition became a public health concern during the interwar years through the work of biochemists, home economists, agronomists, and social workers. It then analyzes how these experts incorporated their assessments as part of rural hygiene programs during the Depression and of food policies during World War II. Finally, the dissertation looks at the convergence of ideas about nutrition in the implementation of public health and development strategies during the postwar years. The dissertation argues that nutrition ideas informed the articulation of political and policy discourses linking Puerto Ricans’ health with issues of agrarian reform, decolonization, and economic development. Scientific innovations, conceptualizations of poverty, anxieties about overpopulation, and political economy priorities interacted in the articulation of nutrition ideas and their policy implications.

This project draws from the historiography of nutrition science and public health as well as from social histories of food and agriculture. The analysis is based on records from government, academic, and philanthropic institutions in Puerto Rico and the United States as well as from collections held at the UN Food and Agriculture Organization’s Archive. Working across these multiple sites compels the historian to reflect on the agendas and contexts that shape the existence and availability of archival sources. Thus, my research also pays attention to how the historical record is preserved, organized, and made accessible. This perspective is crucial for the articulation of a global approach to the history of public health in Latin America and the Caribbean.

Apart from expanding knowledge about the history of nutrition in relation to public health and agriculture, this project also has the objective of contributing to emerging academic and public discussions regarding food systems and chronic disease patterns in Puerto Rico. These initiatives call attention to the links between the high incidence of chronic diseases and the state of the island’s food system. This activity has stemmed from collaboration between academic circles and community based movements advocating for the implementation of policies that take into account how people’s nutrition and public health are negatively affected by Puerto Rico’s dramatic dependence on food imports. Thus, the dissertation project is both a product of and a response to these discussions.
